annotations.text: I dedicate my body and mind, my whole life, to the practice of the Lord Buddha’s teachings in their entirety. I will realize the truth in this lifetime … I will let go of everything and follow the teachings. No matter how much suffering and difficulty I have to endure I will persevere, otherwise there will be no end to my doubts. I will make this life as even and continuous as a single day and night. I will abandon attachments to mind and body and follow the Buddha’s teachings until I know their truth for myself.|Ajahn Chah

excerpts.text: Ajahn Pasanno elucidates the Buddha's similes for the Five Hindrances (MN 39.14). He encourages us to investigate the tone of the mind to identify the presence or absence of hindrances and to delight in the inherent well-being of the mind when the hindrances are relinquished.
Sensual desire is like being in debt. (MN 39.14)
Ill-will is like being sick. (MN 39.14)
Sloth and torpor is like being in prison. (MN 39.14)

When she is talking about the mind at normalcy, her description is having the meditation object always at least in the background, constantly in awareness, being aware of the mind-state and also doing whatever you are doing, walking, washing dishes etc. Her emphasis is on cultivating it so this is something that you would be doing twenty-four hours a day. When Ajahn Chah spoke of normalcy of the mind, did he describe it in the same way?
She talks about within this state of normalcy constantly contemplating the three characteristics of all phenomena occurring in awareness. To me that sounds like juggling a bunch of things!

So the ability to hold the meditation object, go through your daily routines, keep an eye on the mind tone, and watch the stress flavor of all arising phenomenon seems like a fairly advanced practice state to arrive at and maintain twenty-four hours a day.

For a decade, I’ve known it’s a neurological syndrome that many have (R.L.S.) and although it affects other parts of life, e.g., sleep, it’s never so intense as on retreat in the evening. As I calm and cleanse, it actually gets worse, even on longer retreats. If I don’t focus on exhaling calm and mettā, I would drive my neighbors crazy, twitching and squirming like a bored 4 year-old. But I’m not bored and I want to hear the teachings. The level of controlling the legs necessarily, even with calming, creates sometimes a kind of negative pīti—thunderbolts in the body with no delight or rapture! I intuit an ancient root to it but, what to do? Alternative and western guidance have not helped much. From your vast experience of squirming mediators, any advice? excerpts.text: Ajahn Ñāniko and Tan Kassapo: 'Why be a monk?' Sadhu, sadhu, sadhu.

A question for all the bhikkhus: Can you please recall a time when you were intensely attacked by the armies of Mara and had a lot of suffering and what did you do to overcome it? What strategy did you use or whether nothing worked at all and you just had to be patient with it and accept it? Thank you for your teaching.
Can one contemplate pain using the four elements or is here a more direct way to penetrate physical pain? Many thanks for your teachings.

annotations.text: Ajahn Pasanno spent many of his early years as a monk contemplating pain.

excerpts.text: Thank you Ajahn Ñāniko for encouraging us to see Dhamma in hearts around us, and within. Apart from your beloved teachers and tradition, where else in our modern world do you see Dhamma in the hearts of those who also in various ways seek the end of suffering for all? Who particularly inspires you? Who is worthy of respect? For example, your support of Julia Butterfly Hill was inspired by her courage and heart, correct? Also, could a future Buddha be in the Sangha? Is it already happening? Your thoughts, Ajahn Pasanno and those of your esteemed company appreciated.

Thank you so much for these wonderful teachings. Sometimes a very intense light nimitta arises and it feels like all of my energy rushes to my forehead. I try to ignore the nimitta but it gets brighter and undulating. I try to pull it down to my feet but that doesn’t work. I’ve tried all sorts of things but ultimately I just stop sitting; start walking. The nimitta gives me a headache and is draining. 1) Why does it happen? 2) What to do? Deep gratitude.

Following this morning’s talk on non-self, do you have any advice for reflecting on remorse / regret in the context of non-self? Remorse / regret are usually not big in my life except in one area: that of missed obligations to others. Investigation in this area rarely fortifies or informs me. It usually triggers either a well-tuned system of aversion / distraction or else despair. I do have confidence in the Buddha’s teachings and so an inkling that this can all be dismantled somehow. It’s quite a small inkle but it did try to get my attention this morning so any reflections or directions are deeply appreciated.

Sometimes when I sit I get this really strange feeling that parts of my body (arm for example) are moving but I know in reality I have not moved. It’s usually when I’m in deep concentration. Do you know what is happening?
Please tell us what the chant is referring to when it mentions the '3-fold bliss.' Thank you!
Is the ego the same as self? If different, in what ways?

I enjoy the teaching about devas, they seem to be a good counter-balance for left-brain people. Is it correct to say that the Hindu deities are included into the Buddhist universe as higher devas, mighty but not omniscient and impermanent beings? I am particularly interested in Shiva, who for me is a positive symbol of cessation, relinquishment and play of the elements. I know that Brahma is mentioned a lot in the Canon, but what about Shiva? Also, since Thailand borrowed a lot from Indian culture, are there any devotional practices for Hindu deities, and if yes are they somehow integrated with Buddhism, perhaps on a folk level?

I was practicing yogic prāṇāyāma for about a year to alleviate a medical problem. However, as my practice develops I notice effects on the mind particularly during breath retentions. Yogic literature states that there is a complete and spontaneous cessation of breath in full samādhi. Is it true that some scriptural Buddhist sources say that there is a cessation of breath in the fourth jhāna too?

Overall, why do you think there is no application of conscious control of breath in Buddhist practice, e.g., no scriptural references to prolonged exhalations to help calm down the mind? Is it conceivable to speculate that Gautama Buddha did practice prāṇāyāmas with his two teachers before joining the ascetics but somehow did not find them useful?

After the Abhayagiri community begins the retreat with the ceremony of taking dependence, Ajahn Pasanno explains the meaning of dependence, the importance of mindfulness, and how mindfulness connects with the eightfold path. He explains how to look after both oneself and others with mindfulness using the Simile of the Acrobat (SN 47.19).

Ajahn Pasanno reflects upon the question: “What kind of effort do we need to conform with what the Buddha means by mindfulness?” He answers in terms of the four aspects of right effort, the seven qualities of Dhamma the Buddha taught to Upali (AN 7.79), and the Buddha's description of how he crossed the flood (SN 1.1).

The commentary explains sampajañña (clear comprehension / alertness) as clear comprehension of purpose, suitability, domain, and non-delusion. Ajahn Pasanno describes how each of these factors relate to the practice of mindfulness.
Cautioning against trusting our assumptions about the nature of mindfulness, Ajahn Pasanno reviews several key passages in the Satipaṭṭhāna Sutta (MN 10).

excerpts.text: I have a moral dilemma to ask you about. Someone I know, let’s call him Henry (who is also a Buddhist) recently went to the pet store and saw this “bearded dragon” lizard which he felt sorry for and so he bought it and brought it home. Normally, this would be a good thing since it was Henry’s intention to simply take care of the lizard and give it a good home, since the lizard looked sad and miserable at the pet store. Unfortunately, the lizard diet requires that he be fed live baby crickets for hi protein needs. Apparently lizards can’t eat dead things and need some protein for their normal growth. I told Henry that this is really bad, especially for Henry’s karma and the poor crickets. So I told Henry to set the lizard into the wild and let it survive on its own. Henry says that according to his research, 90% of lizards bred in captivity die in the wild. So Henry cannot, in good conscience, set the lizard into the wild, basically giving him a death sentence. Henry does not want this since he cares for the lizard. I then told Henry to give the lizard away to another family. Henry says that this will also cause someone else to have bad karma since the lizard’s dietary needs will be the same. There seems to be no good solution. Would you please comment?

Chah2001.title: Remembering Ajahn Chah Weekend
Chah2001.description: On April 28-29, 2001, over 200 people gathered in Portola Valley to honor the life and teachings of Ajahn Chah. Senior monastic disciples, former monks and nuns, and people who briefly encountered Ajahn Chah recollect their experiences of this great teacher.

WR2005-1.title: Ānāpānasati: Mindfulness of In-and-Out Breathing
WR2005-1.subtitle: Abhayagiri Winter Retreat 2005, part 1
WR2005-1.description: Ajahn Pasanno offered this series of Dhamma talks on the Ānāpānasati Sutta (MN 118) to the Abhayagiri community at the beginning of the 2005 Winter Retreat. These are the most detailed teachings on his favorite meditation technique.

SRD2010.title: Recollections of Ajahn Chah
SRD2010.subtitle: His Life and Teachings
SRD2010.description: During this daylong retreat, Ajahn Pasanno shares teachings and memories of his beloved teacher, Ajahn Chah. By the time of his passing in 1992, Ajahn Chah had become one of the most highly revered Buddhist meditation masters in Thailand. The readings come from a draft version of Ajahn Jayasaro's biography of Ajahn Chah that was published as [Stillness Flowing](Stillness Flowing) in 2018.

SRD2011.title: Tudong Stories at Spirit Rock
SRD2011.description: Ajahn Pasanno offers stories of tudong (wandering pilgrimage) at a daylong event at Spirit Rock Meditation Center

UD2012-4.title: The Gradual Training
UD2012-4.description: Ajahn Pasanno and Ajahn Yatiko describe the Buddha's progressive teaching, which begins by encouraging generosity and virtue and goes on to describe the joys of heaven, the drawbacks in sensuality, the benefits of renunciation, and the Four Noble Truths.

UD2013-1.title: Right Livelihood
UD2013-1.description: Ajahn Pasanno reads from [Buddhist Economics]() and [Constitution for Living]() and answers questions related to the topic of Right Livelihood.

TG2013.title: Abhayagiri Monastic Retreat 2013
TG2013.subtitle: Brightening the Mind
TG2013.description: A classic ten-day Thanksgiving Retreat held at the Angela Center before it closed due to fire damage.

WR2014.title: Our Roots in the Thai Forest Tradition
WR2014.subtitle: Abhayagiri 2014 Winter Retreat
WR2014.description: The Abhayagiri Community take turns reading from translations of the Thai Forest masters. Ajahn Pasanno answers many questions following the readings.

UD2014-1.title: Death and Dying
UD2014-1.description: Sutta readings, reflections, personal stories, and questions about dying, death, and grief.

UD2014-2.title: Thai Forest Tradition
UD2014-2.description: Stories and readings about the origins and characteristics of the Thai Forest tradion.

UD2014-3.title: Mindfulness of Breathing
UD2014-3.description: Ajahn Pasanno describes mindfulness of breathing as a method to firmly establish the mind and develop insight.

DRBU2014.title: Questions and Answers with Dharma Realm Buddhist University
DRBU2014.description: A small group from the Dharma Realm Buddhist University (DRBU) located at the City of Ten Thousand Buddhas (CTTB) spent the morning at Abhayagiri. The group included two bhikkshunis as well as a number of resident volunteers at the CTTB. The students are in DRBU’s Masters of Arts in Buddhist Classics program. This semester the students have been reading various spiritual biographies including the biographies of the Thai Forest masters Ajahn Mun, Ajahn Tate and Ajahn Lee Dhammadharo. The audio is from their question and answer session with Ajahn Pasanno.

TG2014.title: 2014 Thanksgiving Monastic Retreat
TG2014.subtitle: “Just Right” Practice
TG2014.description: A classic ten-day Thanksgiving Retreat held at the Angela Center before it closed due to fire damage.

WR2015.title: The Four Foundations of Mindfulness
WR2015.subtitle: Abhayagiri 2015 Winter Retreat
WR2015.description: Ajahn Pasanno, Ajahn Karuṇadhammo, and Ajahn Ñāṇiko take turns reading suttas and teachings regarding the Four Foundations of Mindfulness. The structure often follows  _Right Mindfulness_ by Ajahn Ṭhānissaro. There are noteworth [slideshows](#WR2015_S07) illustrating the 32 parts of the body.

UD2015-1.title: On Pilgrimage and Tudong
UD2015-1.description: The teachers describe monastic wandering pilgrimages in India, Thailand, and the United States.

UD2015-2.title: The Middle Way of Not-Self
UD2015-2.description: Ajahn Pasanno leads a discussion about the meaning and purpose of the Buddha's teachings on not-self.

SRD2015.title: Desire or Aspiration
SRD2015.subtitle: Can a Buddhist Want Anything?
SRD2015.description: Ajahn Pasanno differentiates between skillful and unskillful desire, distinguishing between two Pāli words that are translated as desire: taṇhā, which is a cause of suffering, and chanda, which is one of the Four Bases of Success.

UD2015-3.title: Buddhist Identity in the Modern World
UD2015-3.description: After introducing the topic of Buddhist identity in the modern world, Ajahn Pasanno leads a discussion around this theme.

UD2015-4.title: Jhāna: A Practical Approach
UD2015-4.description: Ajahn Pasanno explains jhāna as a fundamental clarity and stillness that the mind can experience.

TG2015.title: 2015 Thanksgiving Monastic Retreat
TG2015.subtitle: Mindfulness of Feeling
TG2015.description: A classic ten-day Thanksgiving Retreat held at the Angela Center before it closed due to fire damage.

WR2016.title: Western Disciples of the Thai Forest Tradition
WR2016.subtitle: Abhayagiri Winter Retreat 2016
WR2016.description: During the Winter Retreat 2016 teaching sessions, Abhayagiri monastics took turns reading from senior Western disciples of the Thai Forest Tradition. Ajahn Pasanno and other teachers responded to questions after the readings.

Anniversary2016.title: Abhayagiri's 20th Anniversary
Anniversary2016.description: Many people gathered at Abhayagiri on June 4, 2016, to meet old friends, celebrate and share reflections. Some sessions are not currently included pending teacher consent.

UD2016-2.title: Suttas You've Never Heard Of
UD2016-2.description: Ajahn Pasanno reads and discusses a series of suttas regarding the human condition.

TG2016.title: Thanksgiving Retreat 2016
TG2016.subtitle: The Gradual Path
TG2016.description: A classic ten-day Thanksgiving Retreat held at the Angela Center before it closed due to fire damage.

UD2017-2.title: Two Kinds of Thought and the Removal of Distracting Thoughts
UD2017-2.description: A study and discussion of MN 19: Dvedhāvitakka Sutta and MN 20: Vitakkasaṇṭhāna Sutta.

UD2017-3.title: Practice in a Global Context
UD2017-3.subtitle: Being a Good Citizen
UD2017-3.description: Ajahn Pasanno leads an exploration of the Buddha’s teachings on living in society and how we can apply them today.

Teen2017.title: Teen Weekend 2017
Teen2017.description: This question and answer session was offered as part of the Teen Weekend on September 2, 2017 at Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery.

UD2017-4.title: Can We Function without Attachement?
UD2017-4.description: Ajahn Pasanno discusses clinging and attachment and their antidote: release and relinquishment.

WR2018-2.title: The Teaching and the Training
WR2018-2.subtitle: Eleven interviews with Ajahn Pasanno
WR2018-2.description: Towards the end of Winter Retreat 2018, Tan Suhajjo and the Abhayagiri Community ask Ajahn Pasanno questions related to monastic life.

UD2018-1.title: The New Ajahn Chah Biography
UD2018-1.description: After playing a compilation of video footage of Ajahn Chah from the BBS documentaries, Ajahn Pasanno reads from [Stillness Flowing](), the newly published biography of Ajahn Chah. He focuses on the chapter “[Out of Compassion](Stillness Flowing p. 581),” which describes Ajahn Chah's teachings to the lay community.

Path2019.title: The Path of Practice
Path2019.description: A weekend retreat lead by Ajahn Pasanno at the Victoria Insight Meditation Society in June 2019.

UD2019-4.title: Love, Attachment, and Friendship
UD2019-4.description: Ajahn Pasanno, Ajahn Karuṇadhammo, and Ajahn Ñāṇiko reflect on love, attachment, and friendship while reading from [On Love]().

UD2019-5.title: Developing Skill in Reflective Meditation
UD2019-5.description: Luang Por Pasanno, Ajahn Karunadhammo and Ajahn Nyaniko lead an exploration of the Buddha’s teachings on bringing a specific theme into the mind for reflection during meditation, including choosing and developing fruitful themes and the benefits of this skill.

Stanford2020.title: Stanford Community Dhamma Discussion
Stanford2020.subtitle: Reflections on the Path
Stanford2020.description: Ajahn Pasanno offers a live stream Dhamma talk and Q&A for the Buddhist Community at Stanford (BCAS).

UD2020.title: Living in a Changing Society
UD2020.subtitle: Dealing with Fear, Stress, and Worry and Cultivating Kindness, Patient Endurance, and Harmony

Awaken2021.title: Awaken to the New Year Retreat
Awaken2021.description: An online New Year’s retreat taught by Luang Por Pasanno from January 1 to January 3, 2021 (Malaysian time) organized by the Buddhadhamma Foundation and Bandar Utama Buddhist Society. 350 people in 19 countries participated.

UD2021-1.title: Honoring the Buddha: The Mahāparinibbāna Sutta
UD2021-1.description: Under the umbrella theme of “Devotion & Ritual,” the first Upāsika Day of 2021 was on the topic of Honoring the Buddha: The Mahāparinibbāna Sutta, DN 16.

MValley2021.title: Tea Time Q&A with Ajahn Pasanno
MValley2021.description: Manijeh Motaghy facilitates a question and answer session on Zoom with Venerable Ajahn Pasanno regarding how to use the Buddha’s teachings to relieve the stress of life.

Anniversary2021.title: Abhayagiri 25th Anniversary Retreat
Anniversary2021.subtitle: Nine Days of Dhamma
Anniversary2021.description: In the midst of the coronavirus pandemic, the senior monks of Abhayagiri Monastery offered a nine-day hybrid retreat to celebrate its 25th anniversary. Only two Q&A sessions and a talk by Ajahn Pasanno are currently included in the Archive.

Kathina2021.title: Abhayagiri Kaṭhina 2021
Kathina2021.description: Abhayagiri Monastery spread the 2021 Kaṭhina festival over a period of seven days to accommodate the necessities of the pandemic. Question and answers were recorded on days two and four.

Podcast2023.title: Following the Path of a Forest Monk
Podcast2023.subtitle: A Treasure Mountain podcast
Podcast2023.description: Sol Hanna interviews Ajahn Pasanno about his life as a monk for the [Treasure Mountain Podcast](https://treasuremountain.stream/).

SRD2023.title: Happiness on the Buddhist Path
SRD2023.description: Ajahn Pasanno describes why and how happiness is a key element of effective Dhamma practice. Skillful moderation contributes to an excellent question and answer session.

Madison2023.title: Madison Insight Retreat 2023
Madison2023.description: A weekend residential retreat organized by Madison Insight held at Pine Lake Retreat Center in rural Wisconsin.

Rishikesh2023.title: Interreligious Retreat-Seminar on Dhamma and Non-duality
Rishikesh2023.description: Swami Atmananda invited Ajahn Pasanno to provide a Theravāda perspective on an interfaith weekend retreat at Ajatananda Ashram in Rishikesh, India.

Anniversary2024.title: 28th Anniversary Practice and Study Day
Anniversary2024.description: Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery commemorated its 28th anniversary with a Practice and Study Day on the theme of mindfulness of breathing and the contemplation of death. That evening, senior monks offered reflections on the history of Abhayagiri.

BuddhaDhamma2024.title: On Nibbāna
BuddhaDhamma2024.description: An online guided meditation, Dhamma talk, and question and answer session hosted by the BuddhaDhamma Foundation.

SRD2024.title: Perspectives on Buddhist Practice from Ajahn Chah
SRD2024.subtitle: Virtue, Relinquishment, Awareness, and Liberation
SRD2024.description: Ajahn Pasanno reflects on how Ajahn Chah’s teachings have guided his practice through stories, reflections, periods of meditation, and the opportunity for questions.

Appamada2024.title: Using the Mind to Recollect
Appamada2024.description: An online guided meditation, Dhamma talk, and question and answer session with the Israeli Appamada Dhamma group.

Nanachat2025.title: Questions and Answers at Wat Pah Nanachat
Nanachat2025.description: Ajahn Pasanno answers questions from monastics during tea time at Wat Pah Nanachat on January 2, 2025.

Response.form1: ++Response{s}++|| by {teachers}||{colon}{"." if not text and teachers else " " + text}
Response.usageNotes: An excerpt of any category which has a response annotation will be found when searching for questions.

Teaching.form1: ++Teaching{s}++|| by {teachers}||{colon}{"." if not text else " " + text}

Reflection.form1: ++Reflection{s}++|| by {teachers}||{colon}{"." if not text else " " + text}

Simile.form1: ++Simile{s}++|| from {teachers}||{colon}{"." if not text else " " + text}

Dhamma talk.form1: ++Dhamma talk{s}++|| offered by {teachers}||{colon}{"." if not text else " " + text}

Quote.usageNotes: A quote from the teacher him/herself.

Indirect quote.form2: ++Quote:++ {prefix} “{text}”{' — ' if suffix else ''}{suffix}{'.' if suffix else ''}|| Quoted by {teachers}.
Indirect quote.usageNotes: The teacher quoting someone else. If the person quoted is a teacher, they should get the first tag.

Meditation instruction.form1: ++Meditation instruction{s}++|| from {teachers}||{colon}{"." if not text else " " + text}

Reading.usageNotes: {teachers} should be the author(s) of the book. Use a Read by annotation to indicate who does the reading. If the book appears in the list of references, {teachers} will be set and " by {teachers}" inserted automatically. If not, plug both in manually along with the hyperlink if relevant.

Comment.form1: ++Comment{s}++|| by {teachers}||{colon}{"." if not text else " " + text}

Discussion.form1: ++Discussion{s}++|| led by {teachers}||{colon}{"." if not text else " " + text}

Summary.usageNotes: Used for session excerpts; can be blank. If the session excerpt has a list of items (e. g. readings), the items should be annotations to a summary excerpt.

Read by.form1: {'Read by ' if text else ''}{text}{'.' if text else ''}||{'' if text else 'Read by ' + teachers + '.'}
Read by.usageNotes: If the reader is not a teacher, {teachers} should be empty and {text} specifies the name of the reader.

Translated by.form1: {'Translated by ' if text else ''}{text}{'.' if text else ''}||{'' if text else 'Translated by ' + teachers + '.'}

Asked by.form1: {'Asked by ' if text else ''}{text}{'.' if text else ''}||{'' if text else 'Asked by ' + teachers + '.'}

Fragment.usageNotes: A fragment annotation indicates that the next annotation and its sub-annotations should be duplicated in a separate except following the main excerpt. The Fragment annotation itself is rendered as an audio player to play that excerpt unless text == 'noPlayer'.

Main fragment.usageNotes: A main fragment annotation indicates a fragment should be created from the excerpt and any annotations preceding this annotation. If tags are applied to the main fragment annotation, the fragment excerpt tags are replaced by these tags. Main fragments do not display a separate audio player.

Alternate audio.usageNotes: Specifes an audio file which is treated as if it were the session audio file for this excerpt. Text has the format: filename.mp3|url. End time specifies the duration of the file.

Edited audio.usageNotes: Specifes a replacedment audio file for this excerpt, which is otherwise treated as if it were taken from the session audio file. End time specifies the duration of the excerpt; if blank, use the duration specified by the excerpt start and end times.

Append audio.usageNotes: Append audio after the audio already present in an excerpt. Text specifies the source file and can be one of: <blank>: same source as previous clip; "$": session audio file; "duration|filename|URL": an audio source within the current event folder. URL [optional] indicates the remote URL to download from. Duration [optional] indicates the file's duration. Start and end time specify times in the source file.

Cut audio.usageNotes: Cut the audio between start and end time.

subtags: Non-arising of unarisen evil unskillful qualities
Abandoning of arisen evil unskillful qualities
Path to the Cessation of Suffering

Directed thought and evaluation.note: This tag refers to skillful thinking in meditation. See [Proliferation](tag:) for unskillful thinking.

Happiness.note: The Pāli word sukha includes both pleasure and happiness.

Suffering.note: Although included in the Pāli word dukkha, painful bodily feeling appears under [Pain](tag:).

Pain.note: This tag refers to painful bodily feeling. See [Suffering](tag:) for the more general human experience.

Cause of Suffering.fullTag: Noble Truth of the Cause of Suffering

Cessation of Suffering.fullTag: Noble Truth of the Cessation of Suffering

Sensual desire.note: This tag refers to sensual pleasure (kāma) as well as the desire for it (kāmacchanda).

Proliferation.note: Proliferation (papañca) refers both to unskillful, out-of-control thinking and to the more subtle objectification that positions a subjective self in a world of objective things.

Moods of the mind.note: This tag refers specifically to the Thai phrase _arom kong jit_, and is distinct from the English tag [Emotion](tag:).

Knowing itself.note: This tag includes the Thai Buddhist concept of _poo roo_, the one who knows.

subtags: Thai Forest monasteries in the West

Elders' Council.note: Although the Elders' Council organization coalesced in the 1990s, this tag applies retroactively to the group of European monasteries that formed it.

Thai Forest monasteries in the West.tag: Thai Forest monasteries in the West
Thai Forest monasteries in the West.fullTag: Thai Forest monasteries in the West

supertags: Thai Forest monasteries in the West
Thai Forest monasteries in the West

Culture/Natural environment.note: This tag refers to the the effect of humans on the environment. See [Culture/Natural environment](tag:) for the effect of the environment on humans.

subtags: Acts of goodwill by body, speech, and mind

Environment.note: This tag refers to the effect of the environment on humans. See [Environment](tag:) for the effect of humans on the environment.

Thanksgiving Retreats.description: The Abhayagiri Monastic Thanksgiving retreat was traditionally an annual ten-day residential retreat held at the Angela Center in Santa Rosa, California during the week of Thanksgiving. After the Angela Center closed due to fire damage in 2017 and the COVID pandemic began in 2020, the location, date, duration, and format of this retreat have varied significantly. [More...](about:Event-series#thanksgiving-retreats)

Abhayagiri Winter Retreats.description: During the months of January, February, and March, the resident community of Abhayagiri Monastery ceases all non-essential work to practice meditation. There are usually Dhamma readings nearly every day, some of which end with questions and answers regarding the teachings. [More...](about:Event-series#abhayagiri-winter-retreats)

Spirit Rock Daylongs.description: Senior monks from Abhayagiri typically lead several daylong teaching events each year at Spirit Rock Meditation Center in Woodacre, California. [More...](about:Event-series#spirit-rock-daylongs)

Upāsikā Days.description: Well-organized afternoon teaching sessions held at Abhayagiri Monastery attended by committed supporters. Themes are chosen in advance and touch upon formal meditation practice, devotional practice, sutta study, daily life practice, and social aspects of Dhamma practice. [More...](about:Event-series#upasika-days)

Practice and Study Days.description: Daylong teaching sessions at Abhayagiri Monastery. Less organized and less frequent than Upāsikā Days.

Abhayagiri Anniversary events.description: Commemorations of the founding of Abhayagiri Monastery on June 4, 1996.

Other retreats.description: Multi-day retreats held at venues around the world.

Q&ampA sessions.description: Question and answer sessions with groups of visitors or online participants.

Other.description: Events that don't fit into any of the above categories.

Spirit Rock Meditation Center.address: 5000 Sir Francis Drake Blvd., PO Box 169, Woodacre, CA 94973

Wat Pah Nanachat.address: Bung Wai, Warin Chamrap District, Ubon Ratchathani 34310, Thailand

Cessation of Suffering.progressMemo: Two short excerpts; looking for excerpt relating to 4NT.

Discernment.clusterNote: [Discernment](tag:) (pañña) includes correct perception and skillful choices at any level of refinement. [Investigation of states](tag:) (dhamma-vicaya) refers specifically to identifying skillful and unskillful states of mind in the early stages of meditation. [Appropriate attention](tag:) (yoniso manasikāra) refers to acts of discernment related to the field of attention.

Proliferation.note: Proliferation (papañca) refers both to unskillful, out-of-control thinking and to the more subtle objectification that positions a subjective self in a world of objective things.

Elders' Council.note: Although the Elders' Council organization coalesced in the 1990s, this tag applies retroactively to the group of European monasteries that formed it.

Moods of the mind.note: This tag refers specifically to the Thai phrase _arom kong jit_, and is distinct from the English tag [Emotion](tag:).

Sensual desire.note: This tag refers to sensual pleasure (kāma) as well as the desire for it (kāmacchanda).

Happiness.note: The Pāli word sukha includes both pleasure and happiness.

Pain.note: This tag refers to painful bodily feeling. See [Suffering](tag:) for the more general human experience.

Suffering.note: Although included in the Pāli word dukkha, painful bodily feeling appears under [Pain](tag:).

Directed thought and evaluation.note: This tag refers to skillful thinking in meditation. See [Proliferation](tag:) for unskillful thinking.

Knowing itself.note: This tag includes the Thai Buddhist concept of _poo roo_, the one who knows.

Culture/Natural environment.note: This tag refers to the the effect of humans on the environment. See [Culture/Natural environment](tag:) for the effect of the environment on humans.

Environment.note: This tag refers to the effect of the environment on humans. See [Environment](tag:) for the effect of humans on the environment.
